doc.after: War brought opportunities for expansion for the yard. This meant the building of a steel mill and a sheet metal shop that contained one of the best molds in the country. The steel mill was capable of prefabricating 250 short tons (230Â t) of steel a day. A 1,000-foot (300Â m) building slip was also constructed, costing $500Â thousand (equivalent to $13.6Â million in today's dollars).[2] The yard created a department that was dedicated to the welfare of its workers during this time, as well.[1]
